p: Cancer has been identified as a major public health problem globally. In the United states, cancer is one of the leading causes of mortality [ 1]. In Sub-Saharan Africa, prostate, breast, and cervical cancers are the most common with high incidence rates. The occurrence of these cancers in Sub-Saharan Africa is estimated to double up in next 20 years [ 2]. The cancer incidence rate is estimated to increase 50% by 2030; the burden is mostly expected to increase in low- and middle-income countries [ 3]. The incidence and mortality rate of cancer in low- and middle-income countries are significantly increasing, and Zambia is of no exception [ 4]. In South Africa, the incidence rate and treatment options of lung cancer differ between provinces because the country is diverse in terms of culture and racial groups [ 5]. Although the incidence rate of cancer in Africa is low when compared to other continents in the world, the mortality rates are, however, higher, which significantly reflects poor therapeutic outcomes [ 6].
